awd_titl_txt: Testing and improving methods for efficient annotation through the construction of a large parsed corpus
awd_abstract_narration:
Electronic corpora annotated with linguistic information play a crucial role in natural language processing (NLP) and in linguistic research. Treebanks (corpora annotated with syntactic information) are especially important since they mark the grammatical structure necessary for understanding sentence and discourse meaning. For NLP, treebanks provide testbeds for developing language understanding systems. For linguistic research, they provide the basis for precise and replicable studies of the patterns of use of syntactic forms. Unfortunately, accurate annotation is difficult. Automatic parsers have relatively high error rates and the correction of these errors by human annotators is both slow and itself error-prone. Based on recent advances that Dr. Kroch and his collaborators have made in the creation and quality control of three large treebanks for different languages, Dr. Kroch proposes a major effort to improve corpus construction through the creation of a two-million-word English treebank.  Along with this useful and substantial result, the project will develop and test hypotheses on speeding up treebank construction. The work will be guided by two complementary strategies. The first aims to reduce the parser's error rate by enhancing the part-of-speech (POS) tagged input to the parser while the second aims to make the correction of residual errors more efficient by shifting some of the burden from human to automatic error detection and correction. Speeding up the construction of accurate, consistent treebanks will improve the size and quality of training data for parsers, leading to improved performance in real-world NLP applications that rely on parsing. The availability of larger treebanks and of better methods for constructing them will also improve linguistic research. Moreover, as treebanks grow in size, they will become more useful in literary and historical studies, where the rhetorical structure of texts will become investigable in a more precise way than is currently possible.

In addition to the intellectual merit of the proposed research and the impact it can be expected to have on text-based research that relies on automated processing techniques, the project will provide valuable training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.  In contributing to improvements in automated techniques for language processing, this project may also benefit the analytic needs in industry and government security.

por.por_cntn:
Under this grant, our research team carried out two distinct, though related, activities: digital corpus construction and computational research on improving parser accuracy. With respect to corpus construction, we built and released a corrected and much augmented second edition of the Penn Parsed Corpus of Modern British English (PPCMBE2). We tripled the size of the PPCMBE, so that it now consists of three million words of running text tagged for part of speech and parsed following a detailed annotation system, which it shares with the other corpora of the Penn Parsed Corpora of Historical English series. This system, which we have developed over the years, has also been used to construct annotated digital corpora of several other languages, which have been produced in other countries with the support of the relevant science funding agencies: the Brazilian CNPQ, the British AHRC, the Canadian SSHRC, the Japanese NINJAL, the Icelandic Rannís, and the Portuguese FCT. Like the PPCHE corpora, these annotated resources are used for the study of the historical and the contemporary syntax of their languages. More information about our corpora and the others is available at the following URL: www.ling.upenn.edu/histcorpora. The website includes a detailed description of the text samples that our corpora comprise and of our annotation system.

The importance of our other line of research should also be emphasized, although its results have been preliminary. The increasing scientific and technological value of statistical measurements of linguistic patterns in large-scale corpora of naturally occurring usage has made it urgent that the field have access, among other linguistic features of corpus data, to the detailed syntactic properties of natural-language sentences. As these properties are abstract, they are not easily derivable from the word sequences that constitute printed or digitized texts. Currently, corpora with the high accuracy annotation needed for linguistic research are, at most, a few million words in size; but recently, large digitized text corpora have become available which will allow much more precise linguistic measurements and measurements of rarer phenomena, just as larger telescopes allow better measurements of the observable universe. The sizes of these new corpora are in the range of hundreds of millions of words, so that without new methods like those we pursued in this project, this data will not be accessible to advanced measurements, let alone to the compositional semantic or pragmatic analysis needed for true automatic natural language understanding, which, despite impressive recent technical advances, is still not within reach. Further research along the lines we have initiated is, therefore, indispensable. In consequence, we have continued to follow up independently on the lines of inquiry opened by this grant.
